title.narrative: Surveillance Approaches for Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza

description.narrative: APHIS has supported efforts in South American countries to strengthen biosecurity at livebird markets and to improve surveillance and emergency preparedness for avian influenza, starting with projects conducted in 2014. This project aims at leveraging previous efforts by strengthening the field surveillance to ensure the timely investigation of suspicious cases and the collection of samples for diagnosis. This workshop workshop aims at sharing and harmonizing surveillance approaches for HPAI to ensure the appropriate collection of samples and early detection of HPAI outbreaks.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: Daniel Herche and Tyson Whitney; Ryan Boles

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Salaries and Expenses
Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Salaries and Expenses

title.narrative: Surveillance Approaches for Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza

description.narrative: APHIS has supported efforts in South American countries to strengthen biosecurity at livebird markets and to improve surveillance and emergency preparedness for avian influenza, starting with projects conducted in 2014. This Regional Workshop on Logistical Responses to Avian Health Emergencies for South American Countries occured from August 14-16 in Guayaquil, Ecuador with participants from 11 countries, leveraging previous efforts by strengthening the field surveillance to ensure the timely investigation of suspicious cases and the collection of samples for diagnosis. APHIS subject matter experts attended the training focused on sharing and harmonizing surveillance approaches for Highly Pathanogenic Avian Influenza to ensure the appropriate collection of samples and early detection of HPAI outbreaks.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: Daniel Herche and Tyson Whitney; Ryan Boles

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Salaries and Expenses

title.narrative: Good Emergency Management Practices Development (Phase 1) - Ecuador Poultry Industry

description.narrative: APHIS is leading a project to develop an application that captures and maps poultry production areas in Ecuador with finer granularity. This project analyzes specific production zones based on commodity. Map tools will be developed to identify risk based on proximity to migratory bird pathways, and will include the ability to document the level of biosecurity on farms and backyard production facilities. This projectwill serve as the foundation for an overall surveillance plan for poultry diseases and assist Ecuador's effort to be recognized as free of avian influenza.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: Daniel Herche and Tyson Whitney; Ryan Boles

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Salaries and Expenses

title.narrative: Good Emergency Management Practices Development (Phase 2) - Ecuador Poultry Industry

description.narrative: This is the second of two workshops on avian influenza. During the first workshop, Ecuador's animal health officials identified several gaps in their development of Good Emergency Management Practices (GEMP) in regards to Avian Influenza via a table top simulation with the Latin American Poultry Association and the World Organisation for Animal Health. This follow-up project will support continued development of surveillance for poultry diseases and emergency and contingency plans for poultry disease outbreaks as well as assist Ecuador's effort to be recognized as free of avian influenza.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: Daniel Herche and Tyson Whitney; Ryan Boles

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Salaries and Expenses

description.narrative: The Food for Progress Program provides for the donation of U.S. agricultural commodities to developing countries and emerging democracies that are committed to introducing or expanding free enterprise in their agricultural economies. The program has two primary strategic objectives: (1) increase agricultural productivity and (2) expand trade of agricultural products.
